Research Paper Continuous upgrading of methanol and ethanol to isobutanol by heterogeneous catalysis over Cu-CeO2/AC catalyst and the combination Xing Li Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Software Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization ⁎ Xiaonian Li Supervision Resources Funding acquisition Conceptualization Industrial Catalysis Institute of Zhejiang University of Technology, State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green Chemistry Synthesis Technology, Hangzhou, 310032, People's Republic of China Industrial Catalysis Institute of Zhejiang University of Technology State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green Chemistry Synthesis Technology Hangzhou People's Republic of 310032 China Industrial Catalysis Institute of Zhejiang University of Technology, State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green Chemistry Synthesis Technology, Hangzhou, 310032, People's Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding author. Isobutanol has the highest octane value among several types of butanols and is the most ideal fuel substitute. Developing an efficient continuous production system for synthesis of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol is the key to industrialization. The existing heterogeneous catalysts were all applied to batch reactor systems. The first heterogeneous catalyst, activated carbon supported Cu-CeO2 (Cu-CeO2/AC), with excellent performance for the continuous synthesis system of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol was revealed in this paper. Through XRD, TEM, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, and FT-IR, it was demonstrated that CeO2 not only enhanced the stability of Cu nanoparticles, but also provided a large number of hydroxyl aldehyde condensation active sites. Cu provided dehydrogenation active sites. The synergy of Cu active sites and CeO2 active sites completed the Guerbet reaction cycle. 3Cu-CeO2/AC exhibited a high ethanol conversion rate (81.6 %) and isobutanol selectivity (54.0 %). Finally, based on the analysis of reaction thermodynamics and dynamics, a catalyst combination mode of dehydrogenation + aldol condensation + hydrogenation was proposed, which improved the conversion of ethanol (81 % to 85 %) and selectivity of isobutanol (54 % to 65 %). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cu-CeO2/AC catalyst Methanol Ethanol Isobutanol Catalytic upgrading Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction At present, methanol and ethanol, two renewable low-carbon alcohols, are widely accepted fuel substitutes [1]. However, both ethanol and methanol have defects such as low calorific value, high water solubility and corrosion to the engine. Therefore, methanol and ethanol are not the most ideal fuel additives or fuel substitute [2,3]. Later, researchers discovered that butanol, prepared by upgrading low-carbon alcohols, has high calorific value, low water solubility, and is nonhygroscopic. It can be mixed with gasoline in any ratio without layering, and has low corrosion to the engine [1]. When it is applied, the existing engine, pipelines, materials, etc. need not to be changed. Therefore, it can be directly used as a fuel substitute and is a more ideal gasoline blending component [4]. The isomers of butanol include n-butanol, secondary butanol, tert-butanol, and isobutanol, among which isobutanol has the highest octane number and is also a more ideal fuel substitute for butanol [5–8]. Isobutanol can also be used to synthesize isobutyl acetate, which is a raw material for producing varnish and food seasoning agents; In industry, isobutanol is also used to produce other isobutyl ester products, which are plasticizers used in the production of industrial products such as rubber and plastics; It can also be used to produce artificial musk, fruit essential oils, and synthetic drugs [9]. As an extractant, isobutanol can be used as a solvent for the purification of boron, silver, and barium, as well as for the extraction of some organic compound [10]. The conversion of methanol and ethanol to isobutanol follows the Guerbet mechanism, as shown in Scheme 1 . During the reaction, methanol and ethanol undergo catalytic dehydrogenation to produce formaldehyde and acetaldehyde, respectively. Formaldehyde and acetaldehyde undergo aldol condensation to produce acrolein, which is then hydrogenated to propanol. Propanol and methanol then undergo dehydrogenation to generate propanal and formaldehyde. Formaldehyde then undergoes aldol condensation with formaldehyde to form methacrolein. Methacrolein is hydrogenated to isobutanol [8]. For the upgrading of ethanol to butanol, butanol will continue to undergo Guerbet reaction to generate other products. To synthesize isobutanol through Guerbet reaction has an important advantage: Due to the lack of a hydrogen atom on the α carbon of isobutanol, isobutanol cannot further undergo the Guerbet condensation reaction to produce products with higher carbon. Therefore, as long as the such as esterification and cracking of methanol and ethanol on the catalyst are suppressed, the high selectivity of isobutanol can be achieved. Upgrading of methanol and ethanol to isobutanol through Guerbet mechanism was mostly carried out by homogeneous catalysis in the past. The most used homogeneous catalysts are ruthenium complexes [8,11,12] and manganese complexes [13]. Among them, the ruthenium-based homogeneous catalyst exhibited higher selectivity. But the homogeneous catalysts have problems such as difficulty in separating from the reaction product, the low number of reusable cycles and discontinuous reaction. So, there is still a great distance from the practical large-scale production. The use of heterogeneous catalysts is less. The reported heterogeneous catalysts include copper chromite [14], MgO-supported carbon [15], CuMgAl hydrotalcite [16], and immobilized Ir catalysts [17]. Among them, N functionalized carbon supported IrOx achieved the best catalytic performance. The conversion of ethanol was 50 % and the selectivity of isobutanol was 90 %. Although these heterogeneous catalysts showed high catalytic activity, they were all applied to batch reactor systems, and some catalysts also required the participation of soluble bases. Moreover, the preparation conditions of the catalysts are generally harsh and the process is complex, which is not conducive to mass production. Therefore, the current technology is not able to render isobutanol to be the fuel substitute. In order to overcome this difficulty, it is necessary to r industrialization of synthesis of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol to butanol. Therefore, it is necessary to develop an efficient continuous reaction production system. The supported multiple-metal-component multifunctional catalysts have simple preparation and low cost, and should be the first choice for research. Based on the reaction mechanism of synthesizing isobutanol from methanol and ethanol, the catalyst should have active centers for dehydrogenation, hydrogenation, and aldol condensation and the dispersion of metal active components should be maximized at the same time. The Cu-based catalyst has good hydrogenation/dehydrogenation activity, and the introduction of certain basic metals as the aldol condensation center is in line with the requirements of the reaction mechanism. Based on the above ideas, the non-precious metal Cu, was selected as the hydrogenation/dehydrogenation active site, and basic metal CeO2 was introduced as the aldol condensation site and was supported on activated carbon with high specific surface area. At the same time, the interaction between Cu and CeO2 can effectively suppress the agglomeration of Cu nanoparticles (NPs) and prevent catalyst deactivation. The relationship between the structure and catalytic performance of Cu-CeO2/AC catalysts was studied through a series of characterization such as XRD, TEM, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, and FT-IR. Under the interaction of Cu, CeO2 and activated carbon, the sintering agglomeration and growth of Cu NPs are suppressed. In addition, highly dispersed Cu NPs and CeO2 NPs provide rich hydrogenation/dehydrogenation active sites and aldol condensation active sites, respectively. With the synergy of these active sites, efficient conversion of methanol and ethanol to isobutanol is ultimately fulfilled. Finally, a detailed analysis of the reaction thermodynamics and dynamics was conducted. Based on the obtained results, the combined catalysts were revealed. The three-section catalyst combination mode of dehydrogenation + aldol condensation + hydrogenation effectively improved the performance of the synthesis of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 The xCu-CeO2/AC catalysts 2.1.1 Catalytic performance Firstly, the catalytic performance of all Cu-based catalysts for the synthesis of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol was tested. Reaction conditions are an important factor affecting catalytic performance. The molar ratio of methanol to ethanol is the most significant influencing factor. Therefore, the catalytic performance of 3Cu-CeO2/AC in catalyzing reactions with different molar ratios was first tested and the results were listed in Table 1 . The results showed that the molar ratio of methanol to ethanol had a significant impact on the reaction performance. The higher the ethanol content in the raw material, the lower the selectivity of isobutanol and the higher the selectivity of acetaldehyde. The selectivity of total C4 products decreased, while the selectivity of C4 products other than isobutanol increased and the products became more dispersed. When the molar ratio of methanol to ethanol was 12, the highest ethanol conversion and isobutanol selectivity were achieved. This is because ethanol is more active, and the more ethanol in the raw material, the more acetaldehyde from the dehydrogenation of ethanol. Compared with the condensation of methanol and ethanol, ethanol is more prone to self-condensation reactions. So in order to avoid the conversion of ethanol to butanol, reducing the ethanol content in the raw material can effectively improve the selectivity of isobutanol. The optimal molar ratio of methanol to ethanol is 12. Under optimal conditions, the effect of CeO2 dosage on catalytic performance was investigated. The catalytic performance of catalysts with different Cu/CeO2 ratios was tested, and the results were shown in Table 2 and Fig. 1 . From Table 2, it can be seen that the best catalytic performance was achieved when the Cu/CeO2 ratio was 3. The conversion of ethanol reached 81.6 %, and the selectivity of isobutanol reached 54.0 %. In the synthesis of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol, Cu-CeO2/AC catalysts have several important advantages compared with existing catalysts such as hydrotalcites, Raney copper, ruthenium complexes, and iridium-based catalysts: (1) A fixed bed continuous reaction system is adopted, which is conducive to large-scale production and significantly improves the efficiency of isobutanol production; (2) The preparation of the catalyst is simple and the cost is low; (3) As shown in Fig. 2 , when the catalyst reaches a stable state in the continuous reaction, the conversion of ethanol and the selectivity of isobutanol remain relatively high; (4)There are no carbon containing products (carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, methane, etc.) in the gas phase during the synthesis of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol under the catalysis of the Cu-CeO2/AC catalyst, which has reduced the loss of carbon elements and improved atomic utilization efficiency. From Table 2, it can also be seen that the selectivity and conversion achieved by CeO2/AC and Cu/AC catalysts were very low, and the catalytic performance of all xCu-CeO2/AC catalysts was significantly improved. This indicated that the modifier CeO2 enhanced the catalytic performance of Cu for the Guerbet reaction, and the high catalytic performance of xCu-CeO2/AC was not due to the catalytic activity of CeO2 itself, but to the favorable synergistic effect between Cu and CeO2. The synergy of Cu and CeO2 fulfilled the good catalytic performance. Meanwhile, it can be observed from Fig. 2 that the catalytic performance of the 3Cu-CeO2/AC catalyst decreased with the increase of reaction time, indicating that the catalyst underwent some changes during the reaction. Exploring the causes of this change helps to gain a deeper understanding of the reaction and improve the selectivity of isobutanol. 2.1.2 Catalyst characterization In order to investigate the reasons for the excellent catalytic performance of Cu-CeO2/AC, a series of characterizations were carried out. To obtain information on the metal crystal structure, dispersion, and particle size of Cu-CeO2/AC catalysts before and after reaction, X-ray diffraction analysis on the catalyst was conducted (as shown in Figs. 2-4 ). Firstly, based on the standard spectra, the diffraction peaks of the metallic Cu and CeO2 were determined. After reaction, the diffraction peak intensity of Cu and CeO2 all increased and that of the used Cu/AC increased most, indicating that during the reaction, the metal nanoparticles agglomerated and the ceria effectively prevented the aggregation. Although the ceria modified catalysts exhibited an increase in the size of Cu NPs after reaction, the change was very small compared with the Cu/AC catalyst without ceria. From Fig. 5 , it can be seen that the sizes of Cu nanoparticles of both fresh Cu/AC catalyst and fresh Cu-CeO2/AC catalyst were relatively small (around 5 nm), but the size of Cu in the used Cu/AC catalyst significantly changed to 23 nm, while the sizes of Cu in the used Cu-CeO2/AC catalysts remained around 10 nm. There is a slight difference between the Cu particle size calculated based on the Scherrer formula and the average particle size obtained from the TEM image (Fig. 9) due to different calculation methods, but within a reasonable range. They all indicated that ceria made Cu NPs more stable. That is, ceria limited the sintering agglomeration of Cu NPs, which is also the reason why Cu-CeO2/AC catalysts still have high activity after long-term reactions. Based on the catalyst evaluation data, it can be concluded that the size of Cu NPs has a significant impact on the reaction activity and selectivity of isobutanol. However, it should also be noted that it is not in any case that the smaller the Cu particle size is, the higher the reactivity is. For example, the Cu particle size of 1Cu-CeO2/AC catalyst was the smallest, but it did not show the highest catalytic activity. This may be due to the large amounts of cerium oxide covered the Cu nanoparticles, reduced the hydrogen transfer active sites and limited the dehydrogenation of raw materials and the hydrogenation of intermediate products. To observe the distribution and structural information of metal particles on the catalyst, TEM characterization was conducted. As shown in Fig. 6 , Cu NPs of the fresh Cu/AC were small and evenly dispersed, with a size generally below 10 nm. However, the size of Cu NPs of the used Cu/AC exceeded 20 nm. This is because the interaction between Cu and the support, activated carbon, is relatively weak. During the reaction, smaller Cu NPs will slowly aggregate and grow. The catalytic activity of the aggregated Cu NPs has changed and they can't catalyze dehydrogenation/hydrogenation. In Fig. 7 , it can be observed that the sizes of Cu NPs of 3Cu-CeO2/AC didn't change significantly before and after the reaction. Before the reaction, sizes of Cu NPs were around 10 nm and Cu NPs uniformly dispersed, while after the reaction, Cu NPs still maintained good dispersion. Although the sizes of Cu NPs increased slightly, the change was not significant, with sizes still around 10 nm. This indicated that the basic Ce effectively suppressed the aggregation of Cu NPs during the reaction. This is also an important reason for the high stability of Cu-CeO2/AC catalyst in the synthesis of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol. However, the addition of basic metal cerium is not the more the better. As can be seen from Fig. 9 and Table 2, the 1Cu-CeO2/AC catalyst did not exhibit the best catalytic performance. This is because the excessive amount of CeO2 will cover the dehydrogenation active sites on the one hand, and on the other hand, excessive CeO2 will also aggregate, reducing the exposed basic condensation active sites. Therefore, the amount of CeO2 needs to be well controlled. From the EDX mapping images of 3Cu-CeO2/AC catalyst before and after reaction (Fig. 8 ), it can be observed that the sizes of CeO2 was extremely small (<1 nm) and uniformly dispersed in the selected region, while Cu NPs were larger and uniformly dispersed between CeO2 NPs, which allowed CeO2 NPs to wrap around Cu NPs. The interaction between CeO2, Cu and activated carbon support restricted the aggregation Cu NPs and maintained long-term catalytic activity of the catalyst. On the other hand, the Cu NPs as dehydrogenation/hydrogenation active sites and CeO2 as aldol condensation active sites collaborated to complete the upgrading of low-carbon alcohols to higher alcohols (lower alcohols→lower aldehydes→higher aldehydes→higher alcohols), realizing the conversion of methanol and ethanol to isobutanol. From the results of the infrared test in Fig. 10 , the characteristic peak attributed to the stretching vibration of the OH bond was observed at 3400 cm−1, which was caused by the hydroxyl groups or chemically adsorbed water on the catalyst surface. The absorption peak at 710 cm-1 should be generated by the out of plane bending vibration of the OH bond. The peak at 2900cm−1 may be caused by the stretching vibration of the C-H bond, the peak around 1500 was attributed the stretching vibration peak of C=O, and the absorption peak near 1100cm-1 should be ascribed to the stretching vibration of the C-O-C bond. From this, it can be seen that there were a large number of oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of activated carbon. The presence of these functional groups promoted the anchoring of the loaded metal. After loading the metal, the absorbance of the support decreased and the number of functional groups decreased, which also indirectly proved that the abundant functional groups on the surface of activated carbon had a positive effect on the dispersion of the metal. The H2-TPR results of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 11 . A peak at around 950 K was attributed to the hydrogen consumption of the activated carbon, which should be the reduction of the oxygen-containing groups of the activated carbon at high temperature. This result echoed oxygen-containing groups observed in the infrared spectrum of the activated carbon support in Fig. 10. The reduction peaks of other catalysts at around 835 K was the reduction peak of CeO2. They were promoted by the spillover hydrogen generated by metals [18,19]. For the Cu/AC catalyst, the hydrogen consumption peak of Cu located at around 500 K. For catalysts modified with CeO2, the hydrogen consumption peak of Cu shifted towards the low-temperature region, approximately around 475 K. This indicated a strong interaction between CeO2 and Cu, which promoted the reduction of Cu. In this way, more Cu0 active sites with hydrogen activation ability can be generated, thereby promoting the hydrogenation and dehydrogenation processes in the Guerbet reaction. When the dosage of CeO2 was moderate, the reduction temperature decreased the most. Excessive CeO2 resulted in a decrease in the reduction temperature shift. This may be because when the CeO2 content exceeded the threshold, it led to the aggregation of CeO2 species, thereby weakening the interaction between CeO2 and Cu. On the other hand, CeO2 enhanced the dispersion of Cu, which also promoted the reduction of Cu. CeO2 promoted the reduction of Cu from both geometric and electronic effects. Based on the results of H2-TPR, it can be determined that the reduction activation temperature of the catalyst was above 475 K. After screening, the reduction temperature of the catalyst was set at 523 K. At this temperature, copper oxide can be fully reduced to zero-valent copper, which endows the catalyst with the dehydrogenation/hydrogenation activity. In order to investigate the specific interaction mechanism between Cu and CeO2, XPS characterization was carried out. Cu 2p XPS spectra were shown in Fig. 12 . All catalysts exhibited Cu 2p3/2 peak (around 932 eV) and Cu 2p1/2 peak (around 952 eV). There was no obvious shake-up peak between the two peaks. Zheng et al. reported that Cu+, as a transition state, can easily be transformed into Cu2+and Cu0 through disproportionated reaction during high-temperature reduction [20]. Only Cu0 was detected in XRD, indicating that the reduced Cu species mainly exist in the form of metallic Cu. In summary, the Cu 2p3/2 peak and Cu 2p1/2 peak are mainly attributed to Cu0. Compared with Cu/AC, the XPS peak of Cu0 in CeO2-modified catalysts shifted towards higher binding energy, with the highest shift observed in 3Cu-CeO2/AC. This may be related to the occurrence of Cu2+-O2-Ce4++H2 → Ce3+-□-CuO+H2O (□: oxygen vacancy). The electronic effect can promote the transfer of electrons from Cu to Ce through the Ce3+-□-Cu0 structure, resulting in Cu0 being electron deficient [21]. The Ce3+-□-Cu0 structure can stabilize Cu0. The easy valence variation between Ce43+ and Ce3+ promoted the reduction of Cu. To further confirm the above conclusion, Ce 3d XPS and O 1 s XPS were tested. As shown in Fig. 13 , v '', v ', v', and v represent the four peaks of Ce 3d5/2, while u '', u ', u', and u represent the four peaks of Ce 3d3/2. Among them, the six peaks of v'', v ', v, u'', u', and u were ascribed to the Ce43+ions, while v 'and u' were attributed to the Ce3+ions [22,23]. The Ce3+ content can be obtained by calculating the ratio of the peak area of Ce33+ to the total peak area (Ce3++Ce4+). As shown in Table X, after reduction, the Ce3+ content of 3Cu-CeO2/AC was the highest. Fig. 14 showed the XPS spectra of O 1 s, and the fitting results indicated the presence of three surface oxygen species on the catalyst, namely lattice oxygen (OL), adsorbed oxygen (Oad), and oxygen vacancies (Ov). After reduction, the oxygen vacancy (Ov) content of 3Cu-CeO2/AC was the highest (Table 3 ). The strongest interaction between CeO2 and Cu occurred in 3Cu-CeO2/AC, resulting in the most valence variation between Ce4+ and Ce3+ and the generation of the most Ce3+ and oxygen vacancies. The degree of promotion of Cu reduction and the degree of stabilization of Cu0 were the highest in the 3Cu-CeO2/AC catalyst. All XPS results above were consistent with H2-TPR. In order to directly measure the ability of each catalyst to activate hydrogen, H2-TPD characterization was performed. As shown in Fig. 15 , the desorption peak at around 400 K corresponded to the desorption of hydrogen on metals [24,25]. The desorption peaks in the range of 700–800 K belong to the desorption of spillover hydrogen on CeO2, as these peaks only existed on catalysts with the presence of the metal, while pure CeO2 and AC did not have these peaks. The desorption peak areas of the CeO2-modified catalyst were larger than that of Cu/AC, and the area of 3Cu-CeO2/AC was the largest. The peak area represents the dissociation amount of hydrogen, which reflects the hydrogen dissociation ability of the catalyst. This indicated that CeO2 promoted the reduction of Cu, producing more Cu0, thereby enhancing copper's ability to dissociate hydrogen. The interaction between CeO2 and Cu in 3Cu-CeO2/AC was the strongest, and thus the Cu of 3Cu-CeO2/AC had the strongest ability to activate hydrogen. The above results corresponded to the H2-TPR and XPS results. The peak temperature trend roughly corresponded to that of H2-TPR, and CeO2 reduced the temperature of hydrogen dissociation, indicating that CeO2 increased the activity of hydrogen. The above results indicated that CeO2 enhanced the ability of Cu to activate hydrogen, promoting hydrogen transfer reactions: hydrogenation and dehydrogenation. To investigate the number, types, and strength of basic sites on the Cu-CeO2/AC catalyst, CO2-TPD experiment was conducted (Fig. 16 ). Previous research has revealed that for the Cu /AC catalyst, the CO2 desorption peak at 373 K was ascribed to the desorption of carbon dioxide from the weak basic sites of activated carbon [26]. The CO2 desorption peak of Cu/AC catalyst in the high-temperature range of 545 K to 765 K is generated by the desorption of CO2 from Cu [26]. The catalysts modified with CeO2 exhibited strong CO2 desorption peaks between 300 K-500 K. As the amount of CeO2 increased, the peak area gradually increased and shifted towards the high-temperature region, indicating that these peaks were associated with the desorption of CO2 from CeO2. The amount of the desorbed CO2 followed the order: Cu/AC (0.047mmol/g) < 5Cu-CeO2/AC (0.124mmol/g) < 3Cu-CeO2/AC (0.141mmol/g) < 1Cu-CeO2/AC (0.175mmol/g). The amount of desorbed CO2 represented the number of basic sites, and the introduction of CeO2 greatly increased the number of basic sites in the catalyst. This indicated that CeO2 owned abundant basic sites. It also proved that the addition of cerium oxide produced the basic sites on the surface of the catalysts [27,28]. In addition, according to the study of Li Meijun et al. [27], the incorporation of Cu into the ceria lattice also enhanced the strength of basic sites of CeO2. This structural feature was also observed in TEM images. Compared with the Cu/AC catalyst, the Cu-CeO2/AC catalysts had abundant basic active sites. Takashi and Shuhei et al. have proved that aldol condensation reaction occurs at basic sites [29,30]. Therefore, the abundant cerium oxide basic sites greatly enhanced the catalytic performance for the aldol condensation reactions that generate intermediates such as acrolein and isobutenal. At the same time, CeO2 also played a role in anchoring Cu nanoparticles. Cu NPs acted as dehydrogenation active sites to allow methanol and ethanol to dehydrogenate smoothly. Therefore, the catalysts had both abundant dehydrogenation/hydrogenation active sites and aldehyde condensation active sites, and the synergy of Cu active sites and CeO2 active sites fulfilled the Guerbet reaction cycle. Therefore, Cu and CeO2 jointly promoted the conversion of methanol and ethanol, as well as the generation of isobutanol. 2.1.3 Thermodynamic analysis of the synthesis of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol The thermodynamic properties of chemical reactions determine the direction and limits of the reaction. Therefore, it is necessary to understand the thermodynamic properties of upgrading of methanol and ethanol to isobutanol. According to literature, the reaction process of synthesizing isobutanol from methanol and ethanol includes dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde (Eq. (1)), dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde (Eq. (2)), condensation of formaldehyde and acetaldehyde to acrolein (Eq. (3)), hydrogenation of acrolein to propanal (Eq. (4)), aldol condensation of propanal and formaldehyde to methacrolein (Eq. (5)), hydrogenation of methacrolein to isobutyraldehyde (Eq. (6)), hydrogenation of isobutyraldehyde to isobutanol (Eq. (7)), and self-condensation of acetaldehyde to butenal (Eq. (8)). The thermodynamic data of each reaction was calculated using HSC Chemistry software. (1) CH3CH2OH(g)=CH3CHO(g)+H2 (g) (2) CH3OH(g)=CH2O(g)+H2 (g) (3) CH3CHO(g)+CH2O(g)=C3H4O(g)+H2O(g) (4) C3H4O(g)+H2 (g)=C3H6O(g) (5) C3H6O(g)+CH2O(g)=C4H6O(g)+H2O(g) (6) C4H6O(g)+H2 (g)=C4H8O(g) (7) C4H8O(g)+H2 (g)=C4H10O(g) (8) 2CH3CHO(g)=C4H6O(g)+H2O(g) From Fig. 17 and Table 4 , it can be seen that ethanol was more prone to be dehydrogenated to corresponding aldehydes than methanol. Although the ΔrGm of methanol dehydrogenation to formaldehyde decreased more with the increase of temperature, the ΔrGm1 < ΔrGm2, that was, the dehydrogenation activity of ethanol was much higher than that of methanol. This also partly explained why when the ratio of methanol to ethanol was 1:1, the selectivity of acetaldehyde and the downstream products of acetaldehyde was higher, which was also consistent with the previous experimental results. In Fig. 18 and Table 4, the ΔrGm of the condensation reaction between formaldehyde and acetaldehyde was also significantly lower than that of the self-condensation of acetaldehyde. Considering that acetaldehyde can continue to undergo condensation reaction with the product of self-condensation of acetaldehyde and that isobutanol is the end product of the condensation of formaldehyde and acetaldehyde, in order to achieve high selectivity of isobutanol, it is necessary to reduce the concentration of ethanol in the raw material and thus the concentration of acetaldehyde will be reduced and the side reactions will be suppressed. Thereby, the selectivity of isobutanol will be improved and the excess methanol in the product can be reused. From the overall thermodynamic data, it can be seen that the dehydrogenation of methanol and ethanol was an endothermic process, with a positive ΔrGm and a low equilibrium constant. However, for the condensation and hydrogenation reactions, the ΔrGm was generally less than zero, with a high equilibrium constant. All of these indicated that the dehydrogenation of methanol and ethanol was much more difficult than the subsequent step. Therefore, the dehydrogenation ability of the catalyst is particularly important, indicating that only catalysts with excellent dehydrogenation ability can achieve efficient conversion of methanol and ethanol to isobutanol. 2.1.4 Kinetic investigation of the synthesis of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol In order to confirm the reaction patterns and explore the reaction mechanism, kinetic studies must be conducted. Thermodynamics tells the equilibrium of the system, while dynamics confirms the mechanism. Therefore, a series of kinetic experiments were conducted on the entire Guerbet reaction process (Eqs. (1)-(8)) for the production of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol. For each reaction (equation 1- equation 8), kinetic data (Table S1- Table S8) were first measured. Then, the target product yield and contact time (W/F) were fitted to obtain the functional relationship between the target product yield and W/F at different temperatures (Figure S2-Figure S9). The relationship between reaction rate (r) and W/F was obtained by further differentiating the above functional relationship. According to the expression of reaction rate, lnr=lnk+nlnP, the natural logarithm of reaction rate constant (lnk) and reaction order (n) were obtained through fitting calculation. The fitting curves of lnr to lnP for each reaction were shown in Figure S10-Figure S17. The calculation results of lnk and n at different temperatures for each reaction were shown in Table S9 - Table S16. By substituting the reaction rate constants of each reaction at different temperatures into the Arrhenius formula lnk=- Ea/T · R+lnA and plotting (Figure S18-Figure S25), the activation energy of each reaction step can be calculated (Table 5 ). As shown in Table 6 , the activation energies of methanol dehydrogenation and ethanol dehydrogenation were much higher than those of other reaction steps, and the activation energy of methanol dehydrogenation was higher than that of ethanol dehydrogenation. This was consistent with the results of thermodynamic research. The results of the kinetic experiment indicated that methanol dehydrogenation and ethanol dehydrogenation were more difficult than the subsequent steps, and the dehydrogenation step was the rate-determining step in the entire Guerbet reaction. Therefore, enhancing the dehydrogenation ability of the catalyst is the key to promoting the entire Guerbet reaction and achieving efficient production of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol. However, the ability of a single catalyst is limited. Therefore, the combined catalyst is proposed to enhance the dehydrogenation step. 2.2 The combined catalysts Compared with existing catalysts, the Cu-CeO2/AC catalyst has good catalytic performance for the upgrading of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol and can be applied to a fixed bed reactor continuous production system. In addition, to achieve higher selectivity and yield of isobutanol, catalyst combination has been developed, which has been widely used in practical production [31,32]. The combined catalyst can achieve the performance that a single catalyst is difficult to achieve. According to the results of the kinetic experiment, improving the performance of the dehydrogenation step is the key to enhancing the overall Guerbet reaction performance. The application of combined catalysts can facilitate the enhancement of the dehydrogenation step with high efficiency. 2.2.1 Catalytic performance The Guerbet reaction mechanism mainly includes the following steps: ① dehydrogenation of alcohol to aldehydes; ② aldol condensation of aldehydes to acrolein; ③ hydrogenation of acrolein to aldehydes; ④ hydrogenation of aldehydes to alcohols. For such a complete catalytic cycle, the catalytic active sites required to generate higher alcohols from lower alcohols can be summarized as dehydrogenation/hydrogenation active sites and aldol condensation active sites. Kinetic experiments have shown that the dehydrogenation step is the key step determining the overall reaction performance, and it is necessary to focus on strengthening the dehydrogenation step. Therefore, the catalyst combination mode of dehydrogenation + aldol condensation + hydrogenation can effectively improve the efficiency of the synthesis of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol. In this way, the dehydrogenation step can be rendered the targeted and efficient enhancement. The three-section catalyst combination mode can effectively improve conversion of ethanol and selectivity of isobutanol (Table 6). The reaction equipment was shown in Scheme S26. The fixed bed was filled with three segments of catalysts. Segment A: The feed gas (the mixture of methanol and ethanol) is first passed through the catalyst with hydrogen transfer (dehydrogenation) activity, which can first form dehydrogenation products and then improve the efficiency of converting low-carbon alcohols to higher alcohols on the catalyst of segment B (Cu-CeO2/AC catalyst did not show aldol condensation activity at 483 K); Segment B: The feed gas containing a certain amount of dehydrogenation products was fed into the catalyst (CeO2/AC) with aldol condensation activity for aldol condensation, which can greatly improve the conversion of the raw materials; Segment C: The feed gas containing a large amount of isobutanol and other by-products (aldehydes, esters, alcohols) was entered into the catalyst with hydrogen transfer (hydrogenation) activity, and the previously generated aldehydes can be greatly hydrogenated to alcohols while esters can be hydrogenated to corresponding alcohols. According to Table 5, it can be seen that through the three-segment reaction, under the same material flow rate as the previous catalyst evaluation, the conversion of ethanol increased to 85 %, and the selectivity of isobutanol increased to over 65 %. At the same time, the selectivity of deep condensation coupling products was greatly improved. According to previous research [33], Cu has higher dehydrogenation activity, while Ni and Pd have higher hydrogenation activity. Therefore, after adding metals such as Ni and Pd, the selectivity of aldehydes and esters was reduced, and the selectivity of isobutanol was improved. This indicated the importance of hydrogen transfer activity in the synthesis of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol. As a comparison, the catalytic performance of 3Cu1Ni-CeO2/AC and 3Cu1Pd-CeO2/AC catalysts in the combination catalyst were also evaluated respectively, and the results were listed in Table 7 . Compared with 3Cu-CeO2/AC, the introduction of Pd and Ni obviously improved the selectivity of isobutanol. This was because the introduction of Ni and Pd enhanced the hydrogen transfer activity of the catalyst, promoting the conversion of intermediate products such as propanol, acetaldehyde, and isobutyraldehyde to isobutanol. However, compared with the combined catalysts, the catalytic performance was still inferior to the combined catalysts. From this, it can be seen that the catalytic performance of a single catalyst is limited, and the application of combination catalysts can maximize the catalytic performance. Therefore, the development of combined catalysts is necessary. 2.2.2 Catalyst characterization In order to explain the reasons for the improvement of the performance of upgrading methanol and ethanol to isobutanol by the combined catalysts, some physical and chemical characterizations were carried out on the 3Cu1Ni-CeO2/AC and 3Cu1Pd-CeO2/AC catalysts, which were two components of the combined catalysts. XRD tests were conducted on 3Cu1Ni-CeO2/AC and 3Cu1Pd-CeO2/AC (Figure S27). Except for the characteristic peak of CeO2, both catalysts only have one small characteristic peak of metal with weak intensity, indicating that the metal nanoparticles of both catalysts have small sizes and good dispersion. A diffraction peak of (111) crystal plane appeared between Cu (111) (43.2 °) crystal plane and Ni (111) (44.5 °) crystal plane in 3Cu1Ni-CeO2/AC, indicating the formation of CuNi alloy [34,35]. Similarly, 3Cu1Pd-CeO2/AC exhibited a characteristic peak of (111) crystal plane between Cu (43.2 °) and Pd (40.1 °), which was attributed to the CuPd alloy [36]. TEM (Figure S28) visually displayed the surface morphology of 3Cu1Ni-CeO2/AC and 3Cu1Pd-CeO2/AC. The metal nanoparticles of the two catalysts had small particle sizes, below 10 nm, and were uniformly dispersed. The EDX mapping results (Figure S29-Figure S30) showed that CuNi alloy nanoparticles and CeO2 were uniformly distributed in 3Cu1Ni-CeO2/AC, and CuPd alloy nanoparticles and CeO2 were uniformly distributed in 3Cu1Pd-CeO2/AC. The H2-TPR results of 3Cu1Ni-CeO2/AC and 3Cu1Pd-CeO2/AC were shown in Figure S31. The H2 consumption peak around 460 K was attributed to the reduction of metals. The peak around 780 K belonged to the reduction of CeO2. The hydrogen spillover effect of metals promoted the reduction of CeO2 [18,19]. After adding Pd and Ni, the metal reduction temperature shifted towards lower levels. Pd and Ni promoted the reduction of metals, which was beneficial for the production of active sites such as Cu0, Pd0, and Ni0 that have the ability to activate hydrogen, thereby promoting hydrogen transfer processes, namely hydrogenation and dehydrogenation. The addition of Pd and Ni reduced the reduction temperature of CeO2, indicating that Pd and Ni enhanced the ability of metal for hydrogen activation and spillover. Figure S32 showed the H2-TPD results of 3Cu1Ni-CeO2/AC and 3Cu1Pd-CeO2/AC. The desorption peak in the range of 400–500 K represented the desorption of hydrogen on metals. The peak in the range of 700–800 K belonged to the desorption of spillover hydrogen on CeO2. The introduction of Ni and Pd resulted in a larger desorption peak area of hydrogen on the metal, indicating a stronger ability of Ni and Pd to activate hydrogen. Ni and Pd lowered the desorption temperature of hydrogen on metals, indicating that Ni and Pd increased the activity of hydrogen. The above results indicated that Ni and Pd have a stronger ability to activate hydrogen and higher activity for hydrogenation, which was consistent with previous literature. Therefore, after Ni and Pd were introduced, the hydrogen transfer processes, hydrogenation and dehydrogenation, were promoted. Thereby, the performance of the combined catalysts in catalyzing the synthesis of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol was enhanced. 3 Conclusions In this paper, the first heterogeneous catalyst Cu-CeO2/AC applied to the continuous production of isobutanol from ethanol and methanol was proposed. The strong interaction between CeO2 and Cu suppressed the agglomeration of Cu NPs. CeO2 provided abundant active sites for aldol condensation. Cu was an active site for dehydrogenation and hydrogenation. The synergy of hydrogen transfer active sites and aldol condensation active sites completed the entire reaction process. 3Cu-CeO2/AC achieved 81.6 % ethanol conversion and 54.0 % isobutanol selectivity. Finally, through the study of thermodynamics and dynamics of the reaction, a catalyst combination mode of dehydrogenation + aldol condensation + hydrogenation was proposed, which improved the catalytic performance for the synthesis of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol. coredata.dc:description: Isobutanol has the highest octane value among several types of butanols and is the most ideal fuel substitute. Developing an efficient continuous production system for synthesis of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol is the key to industrialization. The existing heterogeneous catalysts were all applied to batch reactor systems. The first heterogeneous catalyst, activated carbon supported Cu-CeO2 (Cu-CeO2/AC), with excellent performance for the continuous synthesis system of isobutanol from methanol and ethanol was revealed in this paper. Through XRD, TEM, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, and FT-IR, it was demonstrated that CeO2 not only enhanced the stability of Cu nanoparticles, but also provided a large number of hydroxyl aldehyde condensation active sites. Cu provided dehydrogenation active sites. The synergy of Cu active sites and CeO2 active sites completed the Guerbet reaction cycle. 3Cu-CeO2/AC exhibited a high ethanol conversion rate (81.6 %) and isobutanol selectivity (54.0 %). Finally, based on the analysis of reaction thermodynamics and dynamics, a catalyst combination mode of dehydrogenation + aldol condensation + hydrogenation was proposed, which improved the conversion of ethanol (81 % to 85 %) and selectivity of isobutanol (54 % to 65 %).
